classes.name: Deferred
Disposer

jsdoctags.comment: Whether the disposer can be used for multiple dispose cycles.

classes.description:
Tracks cleanup code and runs it upon calling dispose.

By default, the disposer must not be used after it has been disposed. This helps avoid memory leaks by preventing accidental registration of cleanup code. Create the Disposer with multiShot set to
classes.rawdescription:
Tracks cleanup code and runs it upon calling `dispose`.

By default, the disposer must not be used after it has been disposed. This
helps avoid memory leaks by preventing accidental registration of cleanup
code. Create the Disposer with `multiShot` set to

methods.name: addDisposable
methods.rawdescription:
Registers the Disposable to be cleaned up upon `dispose()`.

Must not be called on a one-shot Disposer after it has been disposed.
methods.description:
Registers the Disposable to be cleaned up upon dispose().

Must not be called on a one-shot Disposer after it has been disposed.

methods.name: addFunction
methods.rawdescription:
Registers the function to be called upon `dispose()`.

Must not be called on a one-shot Disposer after it has been disposed.
methods.description:
Registers the function to be called upon dispose().

Must not be called on a one-shot Disposer after it has been disposed.

methods.name: addListener
methods.rawdescription:
Registers the listener at the `eventTarget` and unregisters it upon
`dispose()`.

Must not be called on a one-shot Disposer after it has been disposed.
methods.description:
Registers the listener at the eventTarget and unregisters it upon dispose().

Must not be called on a one-shot Disposer after it has been disposed.

methods.name: dispose
methods.rawdescription:
Disposes all registered cleanup code.

Must be called exactly once for one-shot Disposers, or at least once for
multi-shot disposers.
methods.description:
Disposes all registered cleanup code.

Must be called exactly once for one-shot Disposers, or at least once for multi-shot disposers.

components.name: HeaderComponent
components.template:
Acme

Welcome, {{ user.name }}!
components.sourceCode:
import { Component, Input, Output, EventEmitter } from '@angular/core'; import { User } from './User'; @Component({ selector: 'storybook-header', template: `

Acme

Welcome, {{ user.name }}!
`, styleUrls: ['./header.css'], }) export default class HeaderComponent { @Input() user: User | null = null; @Output() onLogin = new EventEmitter(); @Output() onLogout = new EventEmitter(); @Output() onCreateAccount = new EventEmitter(); }

components.name: PageComponent
components.template:
Pages in Storybook

We recommend building UIs with a component-driven process starting with atomic components and ending with pages.

Render pages with mock data. This makes it easy to build and review page states without needing to navigate to them in your app. Here are some handy patterns for managing page data in Storybook:

  • Use a higher-level connected component. Storybook helps you compose such data from the "args" of child component stories
  • Assemble data in the page component from your services. You can mock these services out using Storybook.

Get a guided tutorial on component-driven development at Storybook tutorials . Read more in the docs .

Tip Adjust the width of the canvas with the Viewports addon in the toolbar
components.sourceCode:
import { Component } from '@angular/core'; import { User } from './User'; @Component({ selector: 'storybook-page', template: `

Pages in Storybook

We recommend building UIs with a component-driven process starting with atomic components and ending with pages.

Render pages with mock data. This makes it easy to build and review page states without needing to navigate to them in your app. Here are some handy patterns for managing page data in Storybook:

  • Use a higher-level connected component. Storybook helps you compose such data from the "args" of child component stories
  • Assemble data in the page component from your services. You can mock these services out using Storybook.

Get a guided tutorial on component-driven development at Storybook tutorials . Read more in the docs .

Tip Adjust the width of the canvas with the Viewports addon in the toolbar
`, styleUrls: ['./page.css'], }) export default class PageComponent { user: User | null = null; doLogout() { this.user = null; } doLogin() { this.user = { name: 'Jane Doe' }; } doCreateAccount() { this.user = { name: 'Jane Doe' }; } }

variables.name: ConnectionStateIndicator
variables.defaultValue:
{
  disconnected: { label: 'Disconnected', icon: 'usb_off' },
  connecting: { label: 'Connecting...', icon: 'usb' },
  connected: { label: 'Connected', icon: 'usb' },
  error: { label: 'Error', icon: 'error_outline' },
  unauthorized: { label: 'Unauthorized', icon: 'warning_amber' },
}

functions.name: checkArgument
functions.description: Ensures the truth of an expression involving one or more parameters to the calling method.

functions.name: checkNotNull
functions.description: Ensures that an object reference passed as a parameter to the calling method is not null or undefined.

functions.name: checkState
functions.description: Ensures the truth of an expression involving the state of the calling instance, but not involving any parameters to the calling method.

functions.name: fixedRetryDelay
functions.description: A RetryDelay that pauses the fixed amount of delayMs between reties

functions.name: maxAttempts
functions.description: A RetryIf that limits the number of attempts to maxAttempts.

functions.name: retry
functions.description: Awaits the completion of the Promise returned by code, and retries if the promise fails to complete.

typealiases.name: DisposableFn
typealiases.description: Function type to be invoked when a disposer clear.

typealiases.name: RetryDelay
typealiases.description: Delays the next retry, after failing the attemptth attempt.

typealiases.name: RetryIf
typealiases.description: Determines whether a next retry should be attempted.
